comments.commentBody: This whole flap centers around the word binder.  Of course it is only a folder that presents possible candidaters, but the feeling is that the ladies presented are somehow reduced to figures and are no longer the capable humans they are.  This becomes a symbol of Romney's insensitivity and callousness.  Romney can bend his record in Massachusettes and at Baine anyway he wants, but policies are empty when they do not serve and honor individuals with all their flaws and sufferings.  We do not want policies that bin us to the past, but free us to explore new possibilities.

A great series.

We need to know how small manufacturing cities and their local restauranteers are doing in Canada, France, or Germany. Do these countries still make their own bicycle seats?

Is what we are experiencing a part of a worldwide phenomenon or mainly limited to this country? Until we know that, we really have no way to figure out what to do about the problem, and no one asks for or gives that background.

The comments here so far are truly lovely in sentiment.

But to really honor Scott's legacy--and ensure that Obamacare is implemented--volunteer at a local Obama campaign office and make phone calls, or better yet, hit the pavement to make sure that we get out the vote!

Rest in peace, Scott.

Putin would have a field day with Romney??? Remember this open mic conversation between Obama and Russian President Medvedev???

Obama: "This is my last election. After my election, I have more flexibility."

Medvedev: "I understand. I will transmit this information to Vladimir."

So enough about women's issues.

If you're worried about:
National Security-Foreign Policy
*Romney's plan to tie the US to Israel makes it difficult for us negotiate with many in the Middle East. In fact, he'd put us into a nuclear WW3 with Iran. He'd also make other people's sons and daughters fight HIS WAR while his sons would become war profiteer$.

The Deficit
*Romney's War would inflate the deficit even further while his tax breaks for the likes of Sheldon Adelson and the Koch brothers would explode the debt even further than Bush II and the income equality gap would be so large that the US would be brought back to a form of slavery, that's the sort of economy Romney is aiming for with his 1%.

Leadership
*Romney's inability to lead his party into the 21st century with regards to equal pay and women's rights proves he's incapable of leading; he follows wherever the wind blows. Putin would have a field day with the US under a President Romney. Anyone who keeps the majority of his wealth in Swiss bank accounts and in the Cayman Islands can't and shouldn't deserve to lead the United States. Besides, who knows what sort of terrorist activities those accounts could be inadvertently funding.

Ed ...  Should we not ask ... how can Romney make $5T in tax cuts revenue-neutral through the elimination of $1.7T in tax expenditures? Should we not ask ... is it worth giving up the mortgage deduction, education tax credits, and the earned income tax so that Mr. Romney can get a further 20% reduction in his 14% income tax rate on investments that are stashed overseas, apparently to avoid a significant US tax liability?  Should we not ask ...  is "who is Barack Obama?" a dog-whistle? Should we not ask ... does saving the banking system, the domestic auto manufacturing cluster, and providing health care for 49 million American count as "failure" to most Americans? Should we not ask ... whether pegging our defense budget to 4% of our GDP, so that it's constrained to fall during a recession, is a dumb idea? And should we not ask ... will our country be stronger or weaker if we give power to a political party who has stated, in the midst of the worst global financial crisis since 1929,  that their primary goal is to make President Obama a 1-term president?

@ Publicus, what a condescending comment. Women should be grateful to have the democrats' support? You would never have known that during the 2008 debates.

As to who "works hard to assure equal opportunity in the workplace," I assert that those in "society" who work to assure women equal opportunity are, overwhelmingly, women. (And all that while they're busy taking care of a society that falls far short of fully taking care of them.)
Women's rights are under attack by Republicans. That's a fact that has a crucial bearing on the upcoming election. The stuff about yelling and squabbling is just trivial stereotyping.

Of course, it was the Roman and Apache men that had already done 99% of the killing and wounding.

Really, its just like what often happens when a guy goes into the kitchen -- there is going to be a mess left behind, and all too often there is a long suffering woman left behind to clean it up.

Richard, I wouldn't worry about your wife finding your post. If she doesn't know how sexist you are by now, she probably won't ever figure it out.
Oh, hilarious.  (where did I  put that sarcasm font?)

Females have an aversion to yelling and squabbling? From whence did this pearl emerge?

I've been watching the women's rights movement since the sixties, cheering it on, doing what I reasonably could do to advance it while still feeding myself. But never in my wildest flights of drunken delirium did I ever believe, even at its most successful, hoped-for outcome, that it would somehow result in women giving up what many men believe is the most recognizable behavioral characteristic of women.

In fairness, the characteristic manifests in men, as well; except not, actually, as virulently. After all, women take things so much more seriously than men: it wasn't Roman MEN who were set loose on a field of battle to cut the throats of the wounded; and it wasn't Apache MEN who were handed over defeated adversaries to be disemboweled.

Women can be quite tetchy, in or out of a binder. As a matter of fact, I'm writing this in the dark, to be sure that my wife doesn't see it: I was warned years ago that one doesn't anger a woman who has a kitchen full of very sharp knives.

There are two salient points here: the uncaring savages are the dregs of this society--they are ignorant and foolish rightists. Second: those making our life decisions are either obscenely rich and/or are USA elected entitled politicians. In neither case should these men (mostly) be allowed near any sentient being.
"Please proceed Governor" was my very favorite moment.  it did Romney in with all his blustery lying.  I want calm and cool in a president, not bluster.

"Americans have a fairly high tolerance for political fights about who’s to blame for our problems. But when it comes to national security, we expect clarity and sobriety. To a man or woman. The president hit just the right note."

Bingo! You hit the nail on the head. In addition, let's hope America still likes fair-play. If congressional obstructionism isn't completely widely-known, the dog-whistling not perceived by all, GOP lies not actively debunked on local news, last night's ugliness in the debate was sure plain for all to see, and it came exclusively from Romney. Romney appeared clumsy, smug, mean, and transparent in his entitled subterfuge. The latent anti-woman, anti-Affirmative Action hidden in a lie boomerang effect is still in full swing. The debate, as seen from Romney's corner of the ring wasn't a pretty sight.

Then, to add yet another insult, Romney's son, Tagg, made an ugly comment about wanting to swing at President Obama.* Romney's scissor-wielding ways and propensity to say inappropriate things seem to be family traits.

In contrast, Obama put Romney back in his place calmly, deliberately, and effectively. He's a class-act, that president of ours. A real class act and a definite keeper!

* http://sherylkaye.com/audio-tagg-romney-would-like-to-take-a-swing-at-pr...

My heart goes out to Scott and his family and friends.

I don't know why you would be shocked at the callous "choices" arguments that the Limbaugh wing of the GOP (about 98% of the party these days) has tossed your way. This ever growing segment of society has been brainwashed into thinking that they are all great American pioneers who are successes of their own rugged individualism. They built it!

This John Galt line of thinking is a reactionary response to try and countermand the liberal social policy successes of the 20th century. It is a very calculated position being furthered by the elite of the Republican Party to try and roll back the clock to Herbert Hoover.

The motives of these "thought leaders" seems to be primarily tax reduction, but they sell it as a mix of intellectual and moral superiority, along with a bit of racism and classism to round out the mix. The GOP in 2012 is an awful lot like the John Birch Society of 1963.

Mitt can't come out for women or minorities as equals because he was raised that way, pure and simple. Up until the 70's, the LDS church discriminated against blacks. Romney's seemingly old-fashioned view of a woman's role don't seem to have been attenuated by his mother's life and work. Come to think of it, none of Romney's values seem to follow his parents'.
Please keep in mind that the core of the current GOP are Southern Baptists whose credo is that women are always subservient to men.

Why Mitt Romney can't seem to come out in favor of equal pay for women who are doing the same job as men baffles me.  By the 1970s most Republicans had no trouble saying they were for equal rights for African Americans, even if they liked the status quo that prevailed before then.  At least they were willing to give the ideal of racial equality lip service in order to get elected.  But they can't seem to take that leap in the 21th century for equality of pay when it comes to women.  Knowing that Romney is a flip flopper and desperate to become president, I fully expected Romney to say in the debate that he was for the Lilly Ledbetter Act.  Silly me.

I was with you until you said "we tried male domination for a few million years..."

First, you should note that the human species is, at most, around 125,000 years old. I am not intimately informed as to the details, but I am aware that not all societies were, or are, dominated by males. Further, while males assumed the positions of leadership in many societies and then held on to them. there are many sources of directing other than those which are apparent by casual observation.

I don't believe women are now entitled to assume the roles once taken be men. I believe women deserve to compete for various levels of success in more or less the same manner as males. This means to me that we could have female presidents of the US for the next 100 years or, in the alternative, only a few. Being equal or having opportunity does not imply winning all the time or most of the time. I further believe that women have every right to influence and change society to reflect their needs and concerns, in the same manner men have for centuries, but I also believe this could, over time, lead to structured inequality and unfairness, just as it once did for women.

As you note, the Mormon Church is set up to perpetuate men in dominance inside and outside the Church. They operate in virtual isolation in Utah with knowledge of their habits and practices largely unknown to most of the nation.

http://terryreport.com
same here Anthony same here

Each and every year 45,000 (minimum) Americans die due to lack of insurance.

On September 11th, less than 3,000 Americans died.

Big-profit health insurers -- who finance opposition to real universal health care to protect shareholder profits and executive compensation -- have more American blood on their hands than Osama Bin Laden could have ever dreamed to have taken.

There, I said the truth -- and I hope that others will respect this comment for stating the truth: it's illogical and immoral for America to spend billions and billions a year fighting a 'war on terror' when this country has failed to grapple with the brutality of its profit-based health care non-system.

The fact that America refuses to insure everyone as a matter of right -- but feels a need to spend so much money 'fighting death' in other less effective ways -- is insane, cruel and barbaric. We make people suffer for lack of health care because we can, and some sick elements of our society feel that doing so is necessary to punish the undeserving...with death.

As an American that has experienced both the brutality of US health non-care and the great humanity of British health care, I'm sorry for your loss, Nicholas. Peace, Scott.

It is a mystery why teachers from K-12th grade are tenured. Tenure is meant to protect the academic freedom of College level, higher education professors. K-12 teaching provides basic knowledge necessary to pass the proficiency tests required to graduate; And, with passing SAT scores, hopefully go to College.

On 7/11/11, the NYT ran an article by Stanley Fish entitled:
'Vocationalism, Academic Freedom and Tenure'. Mr. Fish makes the case for limiting tenure, even in college, to professors who are seeking the truth of a proposition without knowing the outcome. Mr. Fish then goes on to quote a Ms. Naomi Schaefer Riley, from her book: “The Faculty Lounges: and Other Reasons Why You Won’t Get the College Education You Paid For,”

“...[the] additional degrees that colleges have added...have been in vocational areas,” and those areas “...have pre-stipulated goals". “Do we need...to guarantee the academic freedom of professors engaged in teaching...‘Transportation and Materials Moving,’?”

Mr. Fish again quotes Ms. Riley: "...(college) Freshman composition, for example, “does not demand that faculty ask existential questions.” Ditto for courses in “Security and Protective Services,” and “Business Statistics.”

The "tenure" that grammar and high school teachers receive, is a misnomer for job protection, and not for academic freedom, where there cannot be any. This misnomer is also why teachers believe that having 'tenure' gave them to right to teach whatever they wish.

Good points, Alice.

Mr. Obama, this is why Americans were so upset about the dearth of a public option in the health care bill.

As much as we want health care for everyone, we find it sickening to be forced to pay insurance company middlemen -- little more than pseudo investment bankers who invest premium dollars not spent on care in pursuit of profits for shareholders -- or, well, die.

Public option, now!

I live in Greece. In August, I landed in Emergency, had major gut surgery, followed by 12 days in hospital and two weeks of outpatient care. Although perhaps not qualified to judge (the previous time I was in hospital was 47 years earlier), I got what I consider first-class care, from the dinner lady to the surgeon, and all points in between. Friendly, cheerful, professional, concerned.

The cost to me? Zip - save for a single prescription (26 euros), and that I can claim if I can be bothered to do the paperwork.

If Greece can afford to provide such care for its citizens (and, in my case, permanent residents who are citizens of other EU countries), surely the US can. How much longer, I wonder, are so many Americans going to regard ill health as something to make a profit from?

p.

What kind of a weird story is this? The nominal premium in Holland is only about 100 euro. You are insured, why aren't you using it if you have health issues? You have no copayments there to see your huisarts (GP) or get any tests and medications.

It's too bad that you are a low earner, but health care is the one thing that IS available to you.

Dear Mr. Kristoff,

first of all I am so sorry to hear about Scott. Such tragedy. And I am apalled by the terribly comments you describe.

I live in the Netherlands, a country with a so-called good health care system, often used as a reference by the Obama administration. I am a writer and filmmaker, making human rights related documentaries and books. Which is hard in this nowadays cynical country. So I live a poor life. After having traveled to refugee camps I know that our western society isn't all that much and western wealth is . Becain fact mental poverty. This society has lost compassion and love.

Now, I too do not go to a doctor or dentist, because I can't afford it. The health care system in this country, as postively promoted as it is, is not good enough for the poor. I cannot afford the obligatory health insurance and so the little money I earn is being taken from me to the level that I can barely pay the rent and food. And I often can't. Health insurance premium is out of the question with the little money they leave me. Because the government simply blocks my earnings and bank account and takes out that premium plus a fine leaving me caught in an everlasting catch 22.

The system we have lacks too, when people are poor. Just like in your country. And it is horrendous. I observe my health getting poorer every year. And I am certainly not the only one. I hope Obama does not copy what we have here because it won't help.

Alice Anna
www.empowermentfoundation.nl

@marymary
Actually, since this is a double-blinded clinical trial, both the people taking the multivitamins and the people NOT taking them were in fact taking pills and demonstrating the "discipline" you describe. The people taking the placebos had no idea they were being given dummy pills, and the people taking the actual vitamins couldn't be sure of that either.
So you mean if I ate no animal products, but had toast with jam or whipped maple sugar every day for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, I would be healthy?

Huge difference between food-based vitamin products and chemically manipulated vitamins - in terms of how the body absorbs/uses them. I don't know how or what the methodology was in these studies, but all your statements apply to "multi-vitamins" but not specific brands. There is a huge difference. Additionally, the better food-based multi-vitamins usually include herbal ingredients such as nettle, astragalus as well as other add-ins like garlic extracts. These are critical in determining any sort of finding. My vote is with food-based multi-vitamins. Huge, huge difference.
@johannaclear

Sounds like vitamins might be a good idea, but there are so many to choose from now, and many have over 100% of daily allowances---is that healthy?  Or they contain things the FDA has no daily recommended levels for ...

Dear Cazanueva & History,

Yes. I agree. When I politelt requested Colombia legalize drugs that did not infer that the US should not.

Big Pharma madly benefits from this egregious "war" and God forbid you take any drug without giving Big Pharma and Uncle Sam a cut.

And Mr-Ms History: There was something called prohibition. Now there isn't.

Sincerely,

"Those who refuse to learn from history are doomed to repeat it."

Johanna,

Colombia will not be able to legalize drugs unless the US legalizes them first. If they did, the US wouldn't like it. And what does the US do when they don't like something?

Invade countries.

I don't think Colombia would like to be invaded.

Sincerely,

History

Is this insanity? This is insanity.

Legalize.

Solve the root causes of the protest movements, and you will solve the problems, but that will take having REAL leaders in leadership positions, not the mouthy, bought-and-paid-for, gutless incompetents we have now in leadership positions. It is up to the public, "YOU", to make it happen. Put down your gadgets, turn off your TVs, get off your lazy rear ends, take action, get experience, and get involved. Be sincere, and back up your sincerity with ACTION, not words. That will be a step in the right direction.

I think you are exactly right, WJH. And the core social problem in Colombia is jobs. There simply are no opportunities to support your family. And it's getting worse as the government backs the invasion of international mineral coporations who come in and expropriate land. (That's often how the paramilitaries are used, as well as actual government solders.) The people don't have much choice, they need to feed themselves somehow.

FARC is a textbook example of how protest movements turn into organized crime networks. They begin as resistance organizations and resort to underground criminal activity for financial support. Over time the financial aspect becomes primary and the issues the organization was resisting are forgotten or become irrelevant. The Mafia originated as resistance to the Norman invasion of Sicily. Will FARC remember its political aspirations in 30 years? Does it now?

Karen, I agree with you totally, as I do with your other postings.

I have had a similar experience, actually a lot worse - I broke my leg bones (tibia and fibula).

Fortunately for me it happened in a Caribbean island. I was picked up by an ambulance, and had two surgeries with a four day stay at the hospital. The total bill was $ 900.

I needed four more months of outpatient treatment in the US, and the bills here amounted to nearly five thousand dollars. Fortunately again, I had insurance and my out of pocket expense was a few hundred dollars. I didn't have to take a second mortgage!

The problem with our healthcare system is the artificially high cost. People can't afford it because of the high cost. Medicare may go broke for the same reason.

In countries with excellent health care (Canada, Europe, Japan, Australia, etc.) every item costs less. In France for example, an MRI cost $ 200, and here in America we pay around $ 2,000. Why is this?

Please look into this aspect of our healthcare dilemma.

My 61- year old husband took care of himself. Personality responsibility, and then some. Normal weight and cholesterol. Regular exercise. Vegetarian. Two glasses of red wine a day. Retired. Happy. Great health care. Stress free.

Yet, one beautiful April day he had a massive stroke. Two and a half years later, he continues to improve, but still struggles with speech, walking, and right arm weakness.

He is one of the privileged ones to have a health care plan and pension that paid the bills without a hint of push back. Without it, he would not have recovered as well as he has.

Personal responsibility is important, but it cannot prevent all crises from happening.

I wish that all had access to the health care that he had and continues to have, despite his "pre-existing" condition of a stroke.

Mitt can't come out for women or minorities as equals because he was raised that way, pure and simple. Up until the 70's, the LDS church discriminated against blacks. Romney's seemingly old-fashioned view of a woman's role don't seem to have been attenuated by his mother's life and work. Come to think of it, none of Romney's values seem to follow his parents'.
